description.narrative: Women’s, men’s and children’s human rights (civil, social, political and economic) are better protected by strengthened provision of civil registration services and by increased public access to the system.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative:
Outcome 1. 1: Number of ZAGS offices and Jamoats that are fully functional, able to carry out all activities required by law and regulations. 2: % of users of civil registration services (disaggregated by gender and rural/urban, including changes in absolute values) who are satisfied with the quality and affordability of the civil registry system 3. Discrepancy between birth data in civil registry and birth data in the Ministry of Health and Social Protection. 4. Number of procedures (i.e., individual visits, different documents required, different authorizations needed) required for registration of civil acts
Outcome 2. 1. % of children under 2 years old with a birth certificate (disaggregated by gender) 2. % of untimely birth and death registrations in ZAGS is decreasing 3. % of households have all their vital events registered (disaggregated by sex of head of household and province). (Since there is a problem with the documents with the several members in the household, (at least several members of the household have the problem with documents), it is proposed to change indicator from the % of population to the % of households. Especially because the decision makers in the households are the heads of the households and men. It is also proposed the disaggregation by province and not by type of area (rural\urban), as indicator did not show the significant difference by type of area, the difference is showed by province)

comment.narrative:
Outcome 1. 1. 0 (ZAGS) 2. - 48, 2% of users in rural areas and 48,5% of users in urban areas are satisfied with quality and affordability of services of civil registry system. - 48,3% of men and 48,4% of women who used services are satisfied with quality and affordability of services of civil registry system. - 44,7% of users of civil registration services are satisfied with quality and affordability of services on registration of birth. - 52% of users of registration services satisfied with quality and affordability of services on registration of marriage. - 45% of users of civil registration services are satisfied with quality and affordability of services on registration of death. 3. 25,176 4. 5 and more procedures (individual visits) required for registration of civil acts, submitted supporting documents de-facto correspond to de-jure list of supporting documents (as prescribed by the Law of the RT ‘On State Registration of Acts of Civil Status’)
Outcome 2. 1. 84,3% of boys and 81,9% of girls under 2 years of age have birth certificates. 2. 80% births are registered on time. 80% of deaths are registered on time. 3. 82,3% of households have all their vital events registered including: - 82,3% of male- and 81,9% of female-headed households have all their vital events registered. - 75,6 % of households in DRS, 78,4% of households in Dushanbe, 80,6% of households in Khatlon, 88% of households in GBAO and 90,2% of household in Sogd have all their vital events registered

Outcome 1 * Target:1 Legislation is revised and adopted. Regulations to support implementation of the legislation are drafted and adopted. * Target:2 Internal rules and regulations are elaborated and adopted. * Target 3 Staff participate in training once every 4 years. Frequency of participation of ZAGS staff in training and the coverage TBD by the baseline survey. : Capacity needs assessment completed; training programmes developed. * Target 4 Feasibility study conducted on electronic and digitalised registration of civil acts
Output 2 The population of Tajikistan know how to and timely have their vital events recorded in the civil registry system * Target 1 Communication strategy developed and adopted by MoJ; * Target 2 20% of population are aware of the necessity of registering civil acts and of how to do so;

Outcome 1 Result 1 • Draft of Bilateral agreements with Ministries and Agencies involved to the civil registration sphere according to the comments received from the ministries and agencies are revised and improved, submitted to and submitted to the Ministry of Justice and approved by UNDP; • Draft of Instructions for MFA on conducting the registration of civil acts by consular offices revised and improved, submitted to the Ministry of Justice and approved by UNDP. • Draft of amendments to the structure of Department of civil status registration acts under Ministry of Justice of RT regarding creation the structure responding for the maintenance of a Unified Electronic civil registration system produced.
Outcome 1 Result 2 • Draft of amendments to the Regulation on Ministry of Justice of RT and to Regulation on Department of civil status registration acts under Ministry of Justice of RT related to introduction of Unify Electronic civil registration system developed. • Amendments to the Government Regulation #77 On Approval of the forms for civil registry acts dated from February 27, 2010 to make the registration of birth free of charge are drafted, revised as per received comments and submitted to and submitted to the Ministry of Justice and approved by UNDP; • The Draft of Regulation improved on Unified Electronic civil registration system to be submitted to the Ministry of Justice and approved by UNDP.
Outcome 1 Result 3 Capacity Needs Assessments conducted for ZAGS staff and staff of UAGS Headquarters. Recommendations from CNAs in formed development of a 3 part training curriculum, presented to and accepted by MoJ. 3 part training programme developed consisting of a) basic computer skills b) advanced computer skills and data CROIS2 data entry and management c) gender mainstreaming. Training programme rolled out through the Institute for Advanced Legal Education . 300 ZAGS officers trained by November 2018.
Outcome 1 Result 4 The company -Innovations and Reforms Centre (IRC) conducted a Feasibility Study to define institutional capacities and technical requirements for the digitization of Archives in Tajikistan. The Project’s other contractor EPOS conducted a follow-up study to examine the best models for archiving and digitisation based on the experience of their experts from Moldova. EPOS has proposed 3 alternative models for archiving which need to be tested for cost benefit, accuracy of data capture, and sustainability. The pilot digitization of archives will enable the Project to determine the real cost for digitizing in the future and for the planning of financial resources for the next phase. The first digitisation trials are due to begin in November – December 2018.
Outcome 2 Result 1 The Minister of Justice appointed a working group on communications and outreach. An NGO contractor was engaged to support the development of a communications strategy and build capacity of the working group. A one week capacity building workshop was conducted in Khujand for the working group members, and a draft communications strategy developed as a result.
Outcome 2 Result 2 The outreach campaign is yet to commence.

Outcome 1 1. 3 ZAGS Offices 2. Increase from baseline by 20% 3. 10,000 4. 3 procedures (individual visits) required for registration of civil acts submitted supporting documents de-facto correspond to de-jure list of supporting documents
Outcome 2. 1. 90% boys and girls 2. 85 % births are registered on time. 85% of deaths are registered on time 3. 85,3% of households have all their vital events registered including: - 85,3% of male- and 84,9% of female-headed households have all their vital events registered. - 78,6 % of households in DRS, 81,4% of households in Dushanbe , 83,6% of households in Khatlon, 90% of households in GBAO and 93,2% of household in Sogd have all their vital events registered

Outcome 1 1. 2 ZAGS offices (Kulyab city and Rudaki district) are renovated, fully equipped with the model one-stop-shop services, and incremental deployment of CROIS2 is started from April 2019 by order of the MoJ. 2. Due to delay with adoption of amendment to CR legislation in July 2019 the satisfaction level remined unchanged i.e. 48% (F) and 48 (M) 3. Due to delay with adoption of amendment to CR legislation in July 2019 the level of discrepancy between birth data in civil registry and birth data in the Ministry of Health and Social Protection will be defined in 2020 4. Based on the one-stop-shop concept note endorsed/approved by MoJ the renovated and fully equipped 2 ZAGS office have front and back office division and better conditions for citizens, including separate entrance, separate waiting zone with cooling/heating. The queue management system installed and configured in the office which allows automatic management of queue, reporting and monitoring of performance of staff and service delivery time. The new Instruction on conducting civil registration services was drafted by MoJ and expected to be endorsed in Q1 2020.
Outcome 2. 1. 84,3% of boys and 81,9% of girls under 2 years of age have birth certificates. 2. 80% births are registered on time. 80% of deaths are registered on time. 3. 82,3% of households have all their vital events registered including: - 82,3% of male- and 81,9% of female-headed households have all their vital events registered. - 75,6 % of households in DRS, 78,4% of households in Dushanbe, 80,6% of households in Khatlon, 88% of households in GBAO and 90,2% of household in Sogd have all their vital events registered
